bio:
Contributor to Nat Geo
Travel | Photograph | Repeat
Order a copy of our U.S. National Parks coffee table book...25% off for a limited time! 👇

list.comment:
Explore deeper. Most visitors to Dry Tortugas NP come on a day trip via ferry. They snorkel, sit on the beach, walk around Fort Jefferson, and then head back to Key West when the ferry horn blows. I get the need for a quick trip, but whenever possible we like to explore much deeper. We camped for three nights on the island, and the difference between when the tourists were there and when we nearly had the island to ourselves was amazing. We looked at the boat docking in the morning as the time where we would stop exploring and just chill out. But when the boat left with all the tourists, we continued our exploration...and it was awesome. We made friends with the rangers (who invited us to dinner), did a nighttime scorpion walk in the fort, watched the sunset and sunrise from atop the fort, and just had a blast. Yeah, it’s more work and a bit of a hassle to bring all your food, water, and camping gear on the boat. But we so appreciated the extra time once we were there. We left having a deep appreciation for the park, the rangers, and the incredible ecosystem above and below water. Whenever possible, and even when it is more difficult, explore deeper. ·
@DryTortugasNPS (the 51st U.S. National Park) in Florida was established by the @NationalParkService on October 26, 1992.
·

The importance of play time. It’s easy to get wrapped up in a heavy workload and forget to take time to be silly. One of the things that kept us going under such crazy project time and content demands was the time we allocated to NOT working..to simply playing and having fun. It was never a lot of time that we spent just playing, but it was enough to get our minds off the deadlines and remember to find joy in little things. Just enough to fill our proverbial cups back up. In American Samoa NP, we fulfilled our play time by joining the locals (our new friends) for one of their favorite activities...jumping off the bridge between islands into the warm pacific waters. The bridge wasn’t terribly high, but just enough to get your heart going when you stood at the edge. And when you felt the weightlessness of the free fall followed by the warm, salty water enveloping you as you entered, it was pure joy. It only lasted an hour or so, but that refresher kept us going for a long time. Don’t forget to make time to play. ·
@NPSAmericanSamoa (the 50th U.S. National Park) was established by the @NationalParkService on October 31, 1988.
·

Here’s something I’m super thankful for: Fujifilm’s smart engineering of their cameras. In particular, I love that their weather sealing is so good, and that they built in a fantastic interval timer into the system menu. These two elements allowed me to get much needed sleep during a project that did not allow for much downtime, while also still being able to capture the stars at night. Here’s how it worked: I’d setup the camera on a tripod (in a relatively hidden place near our campsite) just as the sun was starting to sink. Through the use of iPhone apps (like my all time favorite @PhotoPills) I’d know exactly where the Milky Way was going to be, at the exact time, and I could easily setup the shot I wanted the camera to take at 2 or 3 in the morning. I’d then set the interval timer on a delay to wake up the camera at the appropriate time, and take a certain number of images (like 100 or 150)...all while I was fast asleep in my sleeping bag. I sometimes had two or three different cameras on tripods setup in different nearby locations. I’d wake up, fully rested for the day, having great images of the night sky. Brilliant! Did I worry about the cameras getting stolen? yeah, sometimes. But covering the tripod and camera with some nearby brush usually hid them well enough. I wouldn’t recommend this trick to everyone as there is certainly a moderate risk of camera loss, but it was a lifesaver for me on this crazy yearlong project. The dry, desert climate and clear open skies of Joshua Tree NP makes it a great place try this trick. ·
@JoshuaTreeNPS (the 54th U.S. National Park) in California was established by the @NationalParkService on October 31, 1994.

I love rocks. One of my favorite courses at university was Geology, and I seriously considered becoming a geologist at one point. Whenever I am wandering in nature, I always have one eye on the rocks below and above (if there are mountains). I’ve traveled with geologists in remote places, and I am always amazed at how they can read the landscape simply by having an understanding of rocks and the underlying geological processes. Pinnacles National Park is a fantastic park for the study of rocks, and in particular, how they relate to tectonic plate movement. Pinnacles is located in central California, on the San Andreas fault (where the Pacific Plate and the North American Plate meet). Forged by volcanic eruptions and fire, the “pinnacle” rocks were split in two by the San Andreas fault. How do we know this? Through geology, it is evident that the rocks on the west side of the fault moved 195 miles north (at a rate of 3-5 centimeters a year). When we visited Pinnacles at the end of our road trip, I remember being blown away by the fact that the rocks before my eyes had been moved almost 200 miles away by tectonic plate movement, and if you were to travel those 200 miles you’d find the same exact rocks. Our world is a magical place indeed. ·
@PinnaclesNPS (the 59th U.S. National Park) was established by the @NationalParkService on January 10, 2013.

location.location_name: Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park

list.comment:
For the love of blue. I can’t tell you how often I see photographers leave a beautiful scene minutes after the sun sets...as if the sun finally setting signifies the show is over. It baffles me. One of my favorite times to photograph is during the “blue hour”...just after the sun goes down (or comes up, if we are talking about sunrises). I love that ethereal glow during this time, when there is still light in the sky but it has taken on a beautiful blue hue. Next time you are out photographing/enjoying a sunset, do yourself a favor and hang out for another hour or so. You just might stumble upon some magic, like I did here in Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park. ·
@BlackCanyonNPS (the 55th U.S. National Park) was established by the @NationalParkService on October 21, 1999.
·

On any large scale project (such as our yearlong road-trip to every national park) that has so many deadlines, requirements, and puzzle pieces, there are always going to be some things you wish you had done differently. Out of the 59 national parks we visited, there are three parks that I feel I didn’t capture them at their best. All told, that’s a relatively small number...but still. My goal was to represent every park in the very best way, because each of them deserve that spotlight. On a yearlong project that had to deal with some seriously difficult seasonality issues, we just couldn’t visit Cuyahoga Valley NP at an optimal time. But I still think we got some nice photos, had some fantastic experiences, and learned why this park is a special one. In the end, I’m ok with what I consider my suboptimal coverage, because under the circumstances we did our very best. But it doesn’t stop me from wanting to go back and giving the park its proper photographic due. Perhaps a visit to the Cuyahoga Valley next summer is in order. Who’s with me?
·
@CuyahogaValleyNPS (the 56th U.S. National Park) was established by the @NationalParkService on October 11, 2000.

I’d seen the St Louis Arch, or the Gateway Arch, when I was very young. My mom grew up in the area, and I remember making a stop here when visiting my grandparents long ago (before they passed on). Even as a youngster I remember thinking it was a beautiful sculpture. Built as a monument to western expansion of the United States, it officially became a National Park in 2018, making it the 60th National Park in the system. We didn’t have a lot of time to explore this beautiful park, as we stopped here on a move to our new home in Denver, Colorado and had two meowing cats in the back of a car while also pulling a trailer full of our household stuff. But as the newest member to the National Park family, we wanted to pay respects and wave at it from across the Mississippi River. We will be back in the spring to do a full treatment of this new national park. ·
@GatewayArchNPS (the 60th U.S. National Park) was established by the @NationalParkService on February 22, 2018.

Spending so much time in nature while we were exploring the national parks, we got to experience some incredible weather. I’ll never forget this storm rolling in to Great Basin National Park. It was sunny not long before this, and you can still see the sun peaking through a small hole in the clouds. But this weather front moved in so quickly that it changed from a rather nice afternoon to an ominous early evening in no time at all. I remember parking the truck (or as we like to call him, “Buck”..named after the dog from the book Call of the Wild) and standing out on the plains feeling the crazy rush of wind and storm move in. It was a powerful feeling that I can still remember so well to this day. ·
@GreatBasinNPS (the 49th U.S. National Park) in Nevada was established by the @NationalParkService on October 27, 1986.

The serendipity of exploration. The first commandment of photography is simply showing up. You don’t really need to have a goal or purpose in mind, but simply being out there and present sets the stage for magic to happen. It doesn’t always happen, and even when you don’t come away from a photowalk with great images you are still left with the positive and healing experience of being out in nature. But sometimes, magic does happen. One of my favorite memories from Saguaro NP was talking an hour photo walk by myself directly out into a field of giant cacti just as the sun was setting. Wandering in the golden light among these giants was glorious. At one point, several coyotes ran past me, barely paying me any attention. And then I found this hummingbird buzzing around the cacti, and managed to get a nice silhouette shot. It was such a fun photo walk, and it all happened because I decided to show up. ·
@saguaronationalpark (the 52nd U.S. National Park) in Arizona was established by the @NationalParkService on October 14, 1994.

location.location_name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve

list.comment:
When I am teaching photography in workshops or expeditions, I get asked the following question a lot: ”What lens should I use today?” While I can always provide a recommendation or two, it’s a question that is hard to answer as the world of photography is infinite and it really depends on what you want to photograph. One thing I can promise is that, if you can only choose one lens, you will almost certainly have a moment where you think to yourself that you should have chosen the other lens. Don’t worry, it happens to me too. How do I get around this dilemma? I almost always carry two camera bodies with two different lenses (a wide angle and a telephoto) attached. There are a lot of practical reasons for this (like not wanting to change lenses in dusty environments, quicker reaction times, etc), but it comes down to being ready for whatever scene catches my eye. You might not think that having a telephoto lens in the beautiful Great Sand Dunes would be a smart lens choice, but when you see that hiker on the distant sand dune, a wide angle lens isn’t going to cut it. Best to be prepared, even though I know that is not possible for everyone (too expensive, too heavy, etc). If that is the case, take solace in the fact that using one lens, and adapting it to whatever situation comes along, will make you a better photographer. It’s not about the gear, it’s about your eye.
·
@GreatSandDunesNPS (the 58th U.S. National Park) was established by the @NationalParkService on September 13, 2004.
·
